title-group.article-title: An overview of acyclotides: Past, present and future

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Review
An overview of acyclotides: Past, present and future

Ramya Tammineni a , Pooja Gulati b , Sanjay Kumar b , Aparajita Mohanty
c, ∗

a
Bioinformatics Infrastructure Facility, Gargi College, University of Delhi , India b
Department of Microbiology, Maharshi Dayanand University, Rohtak, Haryana , India c
Department of Botany, Gargi College, University of Delhi , India
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Acyclotides
Chassatides
Cliotides
Hedyotides
Panitides
Violacin A
A B S T R A C T

Acyclotides are plant-based, acyclic miniproteins with cystine knot motif formed by three conserved disulfide linkages and lack head to tail ligation. Acyclotides may not necessarily be less stable, even though they lack cyclic backbone, as the conserved cystine knot feature provides the required stability. Violacin A was the first acyclotide, isolated from
Viola odorata
in 2006. Until now, acyclotides have been reported from five dicot families ( Violaceae , Rubiaceae , Cucurbitaceae , Solanaceae , Fabaceae ) and one monocot family ( Poaceae ). In Poaceae , only acyclotides have been found whereas in dicot families both cyclotides and acyclotides have been isolated. In last 15 years, several acyclotides with antimicrobial, cytotoxic and hemolytic bioactivities have been discovered. Thus, although many naturally expressed acyclotides do exhibit bioactivities, the linearization of the cyclic peptides may result in loss of bioactivities.

Although, bioactivities of acyclotides are comparable to their cyclic counterparts, the numbers of isolated acyclotides are still few. Further, those discovered, have the scope to be screened for agriculturally important activities (insecticidal, anti-helminthic, molluscicidal) and pharmaceutical properties (anticancer, anti-HIV, immuno-stimulant). The feasibility of application of acyclotides is because of their relatively less complex biological synthesis compared to cyclotides, as the cyclization step is not needed. This attribute facilitates the production of transgenic crops and/or its expression in heterologous organisms, lacking cyclization machinery. Keeping in view the bioactivities and the wide array of emerging potential applications of acyclotides, the present review discusses their distribution in plants, gene and protein structure, biosynthesis, bioactivities and mechanism of action. Further, their potential applications and future perspectives to exploit them in agriculture and pharmaceutical industries have been highlighted.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
∗
Corresponding author.

sec.title: 2. Distribution of acyclotides in plants
3. Gene architecture
sec.p:
In Cucurbitaceae family, both acyclotides and cyclotides are encoded on the same transcript ( Fig. 4 ). Such genes with multiple domains are called TIP-TOP genes and were discovered in
Momordica cochinchinensis ( Mylne et al., 2012 )
. These genes have ER signal and NTPP domains followed by 2–5 mature cyclotide domains and a terminal acyclotide domain preceded by CTPP domain (
). Each cyclotide domain is preceded by NTR domain and followed by CTR domain ( Fig. 4 ). In Poaceae , till now only acyclotides have been isolated and identified from the plant
Panicum laxum
and based on the genus, are termed panitides (
). Analysis of their gene architecture showed that they have an intronless ER signal domain, a NTPP region and a main panitide domain ending with a stop codon at C-terminal end ( Fig. 4 ).

sec.title: 4. Protein structure
5. Biosynthesis of acyclotides
6. Bioactivities of acyclotides
7. Mechanism of action of acyclotides
8. Potential applications of acyclotides
9. Conclusions and future perspectives
sec.p: Keeping in view the future prospects, the first noticeable fact is that, the total number of acyclotides isolated until now, is much less compared to cyclotides. Hence, to increase their numbers as well as diversity, more plants, particularly members of Poaceae which apparently have only acyclotides, can be screened for isolation of more acyclotides. A logical approach before proceeding for isolation would be genome mining/transcriptome analysis using appropriate bioinformatics tools to search for putative acyclotide genes in the available plant genome sequences. This would also require developing bioinformatics search tools for identification of acyclotide genes in plant genomes. Considering the antimicrobial, cytotoxic and hemolytic activities of some acyclotides, more numbers should be assayed to obtain acyclotides with increased potency. Further, other bioactivities such as insecticidal, pesticidal, molluscicidal, anticancer, immunomodulatory and other pharmaceutical activities need to be explored. Although some clues on mechanism of action of acyclotides is available, more investigation is required to establish exact mechanisms. This can facilitate screening and identifying potentially bioactive acyclotides by in silico methods like docking and simulations. Acyclotides do not need cyclization machinery, so their feasibility of transgenic expression for pesticidal activity in agriculturally important plants lacking cyclotides and cyclization machinery is an attractive proposition. Another focus of investigation would be their bulk production by heterologous expression in bacterial cells for agricultural (eg insecticidal sprays) and pharmaceutical (eg peptide-based drugs) purposes which is relatively simpler due to exclusion of cyclization step.
